title: Code cell split-pane scrolling bug
description:
In code cells in preview mode (split-pane layout), scrolling acts on input and output panes together. If the input code is long, the output gets positioned badly in the left pane.

**Expected behavior:** Output pane should probably not scroll (or scroll independently).

**Current behavior:** Both panes scroll together, causing output to be displaced when input is long.

**Location:** Split-pane layout CSS/JS in research_notebook.html (likely in HTML_HEAD or RENDER_FUNCTIONS sections)

reason: Fixed - added height: 100% to both split panes and changed left pane alignment to flex-start so output stays pinned at top

content: Actual fix required multiple CSS changes: (1) viewer-split-pane: height: 100%, (2) viewer-split-left: overflow: hidden + align-items: flex-start, (3) viewer-content:has(.viewer-split-pane): overflow: hidden, (4) viewer-split-right: max-height: calc(90vh - 120px). Key learning: height: 100% chains don't resolve in flex contexts - viewport-based max-height is more reliable.

title: Review claude-mem repo for session card inspiration
description: Review https://github.com/thedotmack/claude-mem for features that might inform our session cards work. The repo appears to have nice UI for summarising, displaying and searching past sessions. Much of it may be overkill but could provide useful ideas for: session summaries, search over past sessions, session display/UI patterns.

reason: Could inform design of session cards feature - better to review before implementation

content:
Reviewed README. Key features that might inform session cards:

**Relevant patterns:**
1. **Auto-generated summaries** - Summaries created at session end via lifecycle hooks
2. **Multi-concept tagging** - Tags like: discovery, problem-solution, pattern, decision, bugfix, feature, refactor
3. **File reference tracking** - Links observations to specific files touched
4. **Progressive disclosure** - Layered retrieval showing token costs for context decisions
5. **Hybrid search** - Keyword (FTS5) + semantic (Chroma vector) search
6. **Web viewer UI** - Real-time visualization at localhost:37777

**Likely overkill for us:**
- Lifecycle hooks intercepting every tool use
- Full SQLite + vector DB infrastructure
- MCP integration
- Endless Mode (context compression)

**Architecture:** TypeScript/Bun worker service on port 37777, SQLite with FTS5 for storage, Chroma for semantic search, Claude Agent SDK for extracting learnings from tool outputs.

UI Code Review - Key patterns:

**Summary Card (SummaryCard.tsx)**
- Structured sections: Investigated, Learned, Completed, Next Steps (each with icon)
- Request/title at top, project badge, session ID and timestamp in footer
- Amber/gold color scheme to distinguish from other card types

**Observation Card (ObservationCard.tsx)**
- Progressive disclosure via toggle buttons: subtitle (default) → facts (bullet list) → narrative (full text)
- Type badge (decision, bugfix, feature, refactor, etc.)
- Metadata: concepts as small badges, files read/modified
- Toggle buttons in header: 'facts' and 'narrative' - only one active at a time

**Feed (Feed.tsx)**
- Simple chronological feed combining observations, summaries, prompts
- Sorted by created_at_epoch descending
- Infinite scroll via IntersectionObserver

**Color coding by card type:**
- Summary: amber/gold (--color-bg-summary, --color-border-summary)
- Prompt: purple 
- Observation: blue

**CSS patterns:**
- Comprehensive CSS variable system (light + dark themes)
- Cards expand in-place with toggles (no modal viewer)
- Type badges: uppercase, small, colored background

**Data model (types.ts):**
- Observation: type, title, subtitle, narrative, facts (JSON array), concepts (JSON array), files_read, files_modified
- Summary: request, investigated, learned, completed, next_steps
- Both have: id, project, created_at_epoch

Design Implications for Sessions Skill / Session Cards:

**Current sessions skill structure:**
- learnings (array) ✓ maps to 'learned'
- open_questions (array) - unique to our skill
- next_actions (array) ✓ maps to 'next_steps'
- issues_worked (array) - could inform 'completed'

**Claude-mem summary structure:**
- investigated - what was explored
- learned - key discoveries
- completed - what got done
- next_steps - follow-up items

**Gap analysis:**
1. We lack 'investigated' - what areas/files were explored
2. We lack explicit 'completed' - issues_worked is indirect
3. We have open_questions which they don't (valuable, keep)

**Two approaches for session cards:**

A) **Full transcripts** (current design doc approach)
- Import raw Claude Code JSONL
- Complex hierarchical viewer with expand/collapse
- Large files, rich detail but hard to scan

B) **Structured summaries** (claude-mem inspired)
- Use sessions skill to capture structured data as we go
- Cards display sections: Explored | Learned | Completed | Next Steps | Open Questions
- Smaller, scannable, but loses transcript detail

**Hybrid approach:**
- Session cards store BOTH structured summary AND raw transcript
- Card preview shows structured summary (scannable)
- Viewer offers 'Full Transcript' tab for drill-down
- Sessions skill evolves to capture richer structure during session

**Possible sessions skill field additions:**
- explored/investigated: files/areas touched
- completed: tasks finished (derive from issues closed?)
- decisions: key choices made (currently mixed into learnings)

reason:
Done - Reviewed claude-mem repo and extracted design lessons:

1. Added 'Structured Summaries' section to dev/planning/features/session-card-type.md
2. Key pattern: Structured sections (Explored/Learned/Completed/Next Steps) instead of raw transcripts
3. Proposed hybrid approach: structured summary for cards + optional transcript for drill-down
4. Identified sessions skill evolution: add 'explored', 'completed', 'decisions' fields
5. Progressive disclosure UI pattern from claude-mem (toggle buttons)

Reference: Issue notes contain full review findings from README and UI code analysis.

With the hybrid approach from claude-mem review (#010):

title: Consolidate markdown typography CSS
description: The markdown content styles are duplicated between .preview-content (card previews) and .viewer-markdown (viewer modal). These share the same typography rules (h1-h6, lists, tables, code blocks, blockquotes) but are defined separately. Consolidating into shared classes could reduce CSS by ~15-20% and improve maintainability. Low risk refactor - purely cosmetic change.

content: Expanded scope: markdown typography is duplicated in THREE places, not two: .preview-content (card), .viewer-markdown (viewer), and .viewer-description (bookmark descriptions). Also identified: (1) code block styling duplicated between .preview-code and .viewer-code-only, (2) split pane layouts duplicated between preview-split-* and viewer-split-*. Suggested approach: create shared base classes (.md-content, .code-block) with context-specific overrides only where needed.

Expanded scope: CSS architecture refactor using cascade layers. Design doc: dev/planning/architecture/css-layers-design.md. Three phases: (1) Add layer infrastructure and inline hljs theme, (2) Organize existing CSS into layers, (3) Consolidate shared patterns like .md-content. Primary benefit: theme.css can override any style without !important.

title: CSS layers phase 1: Infrastructure
description: Add @layer declarations, inline highlight.js atom-one-dark theme in vendors layer, remove CDN link for CSS (keep JS), remove !important from hljs overrides.

title: CSS layers phase 2: Organize into layers

Implementation complete on feature/skill-integration branch but blocked on skill config question.

**Issue:** research-notebook is a special case - it develops the notebook app, not a notebook of content. The dev/ folder is the natural notebook for development work, so sessions/issues should appear there (dev/.issues/, dev/.memory/) not at repo root.

**Problem:** Skills use symlinked directories, so we can't shadow with local config.yaml inside the skill folder. Putting config outside the skill folder feels hacky and breaks self-containment.

**Options explored:**
1. Environment variable - unclear when/how it gets set
2. Config file next to symlink (outside skill dir) - breaks self-containment
3. Command-line args with CLAUDE.md coordination - error-prone
4. Copy skill instead of symlink - loses auto-updates

**Decision:** Needs more thought. Parking this to discuss skill configuration patterns.

title: Notebook root auto-discovery
description: Auto-detect .notebook/ in subdirectories when opening parent. See dev/planning/features/repo-dev-companion.md

content:
Problem: File System Access API grants permissions per directory tree. Opening subdirectory (dev/) doesn't grant access to parent resources (.memory/, .issues/).

Solution: Open parent for permissions, auto-detect subdirectories with .notebook/, prompt user to select which notebook to open.

Bonus: Enables switching between multiple notebooks in a monorepo.

Unblocks: Session cards (#005) working in dev notebook scenario.

Design doc: dev/planning/features/repo-dev-companion.md (Option A)
Created issue #018 (Notebook root auto-discovery) to address the permission scope limitation blocking session cards in dev notebook. This is the clean architectural fix rather than a workaround.

title: Decision: CLAUDE.md initialization for notebooks
description:
Decide how notebooks get CLAUDE.md for Claude Code integration.

**ADR:** dev/planning/architecture/multi-file-architecture.md (Open Question 1)

**Options:**
a. CLI initializer: python scripts/init_notebook.py /path/to/notebook
b. App button: 'Initialize for Claude Code' in toolbar/settings
c. Documentation only: 'Copy defaults/CLAUDE.md to your notebook'
d. Auto-create on first save: ensure CLAUDE.md exists when any card is saved

**Considerations:**
- Claude Code needs CLAUDE.md in notebook directory to work
- Users may not realize this requirement
- Option (b) provides discoverability
- Option (d) is most seamless but may create files unexpectedly

**Outcome:** Document decision in ADR
